case_name: Durga Charan Naik & Ors. v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1964 was filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 67 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Orissa High Court delivered judgment and order dated March 2, 1964 in Government Appeal No. 49 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated March 2, 1964 of the Orissa High Court in Government Appeal No. 49 of 1963.

facts.text: Orissa High Court set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Puri.

anchor.surface_text: by which the High Court set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Puri and convicted the appellants under s. 353

facts.text: Orissa High Court convicted the appellants under section 353 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to 4 months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: and convicted the appellants under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to 4 months rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Decree-holders Panu Sahu and Naha Sahu levied execution of decree Ex. Case No. 125/62 in the Court of the Munsif, Puri against the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holders Panu Sahu and Naha Sahu levied execution of the decree  Ex. Case No. 125/62  in the Court of the Munsif, Puri against the appellants

facts.text: Writ of attachment of the moveables of the judgment-debtor was issued for execution through P.W. 2, Sadhu Charan Mohanty, returnable by August 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: and a writ of attachment of the moveables of the judgment-debtor was issued for execution through P.W. 2, Sadhu Charan Mohanty, a peon of the Civil Court, Puri, returnable by August 10, 1962.

facts.text: P.W. 2 reached the village of the judgment-debtors on August 10, 1962 at 10 a.m. with the warrant of attachment.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 2 reached the village of the judgment-debtors on August 10, 1962 at 10 a.m. with the warrant of attachment and asked the judgment-debtors to pay the decretal dues

facts.text: P.W. 2 asked the judgment-debtors to pay the decretal dues of Rs. 952 - 10 nP.

anchor.surface_text: and asked the judgment-debtors to pay the decretal dues of Rs. 952 - 10 nP, and when he was going to seize some of the moveables,

facts.text: Appellants came to the spot with lathis and resisted P.W. 2 when he was going to seize moveables.

anchor.surface_text: the appellants came there with lathis and resisted him. W. 2 sent a report-Ex. 4-to the Court through Nabaghan requesting the Court to give necessary police help.

facts.text: P.W. 2 sent report Ex. 4 to the Court requesting police help on August 10, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: W. 2 sent a report-Ex. 4-to the Court through Nabaghan requesting the Court to give necessary police help. Accordingly on the same day the Munsif wrote a letter,

facts.text: Munsif wrote letter Ex. 2 on the same day requesting Superintendent of Police, Puri for police help.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly on the same day the Munsif wrote a letter, Ex. 2, requesting the Superintendent of Police, Puri to direct the Officer-in-charge, Sadar Police Station, to give immediate police help to the process server.

facts.text: P.W. 1, Assistant Sub-Inspector of Sadar Police Station, Puri was deputed with two constables including P.W. 3.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this letter, P.W. 1, the Assistant Sub.Inspector, Sadar Police Station, Puri was deputed along with two constables including P.W. 3, Constable number 613.

facts.text: Police party went to village Sanua with P.W. 6 Naib Sarpanch and P.W. 8 Chowkidar of village Chhaitna.

anchor.surface_text: They went to the village Sanua where the writ of attachment was to be executed P.W. 6 the Naib Sarpanch and P.W. 8 the Chowkidar of the village Chhaitna also accompanied them.

facts.text: Police found P.W. 2 sitting in front of house of Durga Charan Naik, one of the judgment-debtors.

anchor.surface_text: On reaching the spot, they found P.W. 2 sitting in front of the house of Durga Charan Naik-One of the judgment-debtors.

facts.text: Fakir Charan Naik, father of Durga Charan Naik, paid Rs. 952-10 nP to P.W. 2 and obtained receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The A.S.I. then called out Fakir Charan Naik, father of Durga Charan Naik one of the judgment-debtors, who opened the door and paid Rs. 952 - 10 nP to the process server,

facts.text: At about 7 p.m. while crossing a river in a boat, P.W. 1 saw appellant Durga Charan with 10 or 12 persons coming from opposite direction.

anchor.surface_text: After the money was paid, all of them left the village and at about 7 p.m. while they were crossing a river nearby in a boat, P.W. I saw the appellant Durga Charan with 10 or 12 persons coming from the opposite direction.

facts.text: P.W. 1 directed P.W. 2 to hand over the money to chowkidar P.W. 8.

anchor.surface_text: On seeing them, P.W. I apprehended some trouble and directed P.W. 2 to hand over the money to the chowkidar, P.W. 8.

facts.text: Appellant Durga Charan forcibly dragged the A.S.I.

anchor.surface_text: When all of them got down from the boat, appellant Durga Charan forcibly dragged the A.S.I.

facts.text: Durga Charan threatened to assault the A.S.I. if he did not return the money.

anchor.surface_text: A number of other persons including the other appellants assembled at the spot. Durga Charan threatened to assault the A.S.1 if he did number return the money.

facts.text: Durga Charan searched the pockets of the A.S.I.

anchor.surface_text: Durga Charan also searched hi pockets and Netrananda threatened the A.S.I.

facts.text: Netrananda threatened the A.S.I. that he would not leave until money returned.

anchor.surface_text: Durga Charan also searched hi pockets and Netrananda threatened the A.S.I. by saying that he would number leave the place until the money was returned.

facts.text: Netrananda obstructed P.W. 1 by holding his right hand when he wanted to write a report.

anchor.surface_text: When P.W. I wanted to write a report to his police station, Netrananda MllSup.Cl/66-9 obstructed him by holding his right hand.

facts.text: Bipra and Jugal caught hold of the hands of P.W. 2 and took him to the river bank demanding return of money.

anchor.surface_text: Bipra and Jugal caught hold of the hands of P.W. 2 and took him to the river bank and demanded return of the money.

facts.text: P.W. 1 lodged first information report at police station next morning.

anchor.surface_text: Then at the intervention of some outsiders the appellants left the spot. W. I lodged the first information report at the police station next morning

facts.text: After investigation, appellants were charge sheeted and committed to Court of Sessions.

anchor.surface_text: and after investigation the appellants were charge sheeted and companymitted to the companyrt of Sessions.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants of all charges.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Sessions Judge acquitted the appellants of all the charges.

facts.text: State Government appealed to Orissa High Court which convicted 4 appellants under s.353 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government took the matter in appeal to the Orissa High Court which set aside the order of acquittal with regard to the 4 appellants and companyvicted them under s. 353, Indian Penal Code.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 2, 1964 of the Orissa High Court in Government Appeal No. 49 of 1963.

This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Orissa High Court dated March 2, 1964 in Government Appeal No. 49 of 1963 by which the High Court set aside the order of acquittal passed by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Puri and convicted the appellants under s. 353

convicted the appellants under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced them to 4 months rigorous imprisonment. The decree-holders Panu Sahu and Naha Sahu levied execution of the decree  Ex. Case No. 125/62  in the Court of the Munsif, Puri against the appellants

issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Additional Sessions Judge under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code

anchor.surface_text: In support of this appeal Mr. Garg submitted, in the first place, that the High Court had no justification for interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Additional Sessions Judge and that it has no applied the correct principle in a matter of this description. Learned Counsel took us through

issues.text: Whether the conviction of the appellants under s. 353 Indian Penal Code is illegal because of contravention of s. 195(1) Criminal Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: We pass on to consider the next contention of the appellants that the conviction of the appellants under s. 353, Indian Penal Code is illegal because there is a contravention of s.195 (1) of the Criminal Procedure Code which requires a complaint in writing by the process server or the A.S.I.

issues.text: Whether ss. 186 and 353 Indian Penal Code relate to two distinct offences

anchor.surface_text: the charge under s. 353, Indian Penal Code is based are the same as those constituting the charge under s. 186, Indian Penal Code but it cannot be ignored that ss. 186 and 353, Indian Penal Code relate to two distinct offences

issues.text: Whether s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code bars the trial of an accused for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but not within its ambit

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but which is not within the ambit of that section.

arguments.claim: Prosecution under s. 186 IPC was barred under s. 195 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: As regards the charge under s. 186, Indian Penal Code, the High Court expressed the view that the prosecution was barred under the provisions of s. 195, Criminal Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Conviction under s. 353 IPC is illegal due to contravention of s. 195(1) CrPC requiring complaint by public servant

anchor.surface_text: the next contention of the appellants that the conviction of the appellants under s. 353, Indian Penal Code is illegal because there is a contravention of s.195 (1) of the Criminal Procedure Code which requires a complaint in writing by the process server or the A.S.I.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mpanyld be taken of the offence under S. 186, Indian Penal Code unless there was a companyplaint in writing as required by s. 195 1  of the Criminal P

arguments.court_reasoning: s. 353 and s. 186 are distinct offences with different ingredients; s. 195 does not bar prosecution for distinct offence on same facts

arguments.claim: Charge under s. 353 based on same facts as s. 186; conviction under s. 353 circumvents s. 195 CrPC requirement

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted that the charge under s. 353, Indian Penal Code is based upon the same facts as the charge under s. 186, Indian Penal Code and no cognizance could be taken of the offence under S. 186... tantamount to a circumvention of the requirement of s. 195

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mpanyld be taken of the offence under S. 186, Indian Penal Code unless there was a companyplaint in writing as required by s. 195 1  of the Criminal P

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinct offences allow separate prosecution; not evasion as ingredients differ (criminal force required for s. 353); cites Satis Chandra, Basir-ul-Huq, Hori Ram

arguments.claim: Appellate court has full power to review entire evidence in acquittal appeal and reverse if not justified

anchor.surface_text: In Sanwat Singh Others v. State of Rajasthan it was pointed out by this Court that an appellate court has full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal is founded and that the principles laid down by the Judicial Committee in Sheo Swarups case afford a correct guide

arguments.claim: Powers under s. 423(1)(a) CrPC for acquittal appeals as wide as for conviction appeals; no rigid test required

anchor.surface_text: the power conferred by cl. (a) of s. 423 (1) which deals with an appeal against an order of acquittal is as wide as the power conferred by cl. (b) which deals with an appeal against an order of conviction

arguments.claim: ss. 186 and 353 IPC relate to two distinct offences with different ingredients

anchor.surface_text: but it cannot be ignored that ss. 186 and 353, Indian Penal Code relate to two distinct offences and while the offence under the latter section is a cognizable offence, the one under the former section is not so. The ingredients of the two offences are also distinct.

arguments.claim: s. 195 CrPC does not bar trial for a distinct offence disclosed by the same facts but outside its ambit

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but which is not within the ambit of that section.

arguments.claim: Prosecution under s. 353 not evasion or camouflage of s. 195 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellants Mr. Garg suggested that the prosecution of the appellants under s. 353, Indian Penal Code was by way of evasion of the requirements of s. 195, Criminal Procedure Code. But we are satisfied that there is no substance in this argument and there is no camouflage or evasion in the present case.

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Additional Sessions Judge with regard to the charge under s. 353, Indian Penal Code and the judgment of the High Court is not vitiated by any error of law.

anchor.surface_text: Tested in the light of these principles laid down by those authorities, we are satisfied that the High Court was justified, in the present case, in interfering with the order of acquittal passed by the Additional Sessions Judge with regard to the charge under S. 353, Indian Penal Code and the judgment of the High Court is not vitiated by any error of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied principles from Sanwat Singh, Sheo Swarup, and M.G. Agarwal allowing full evidentiary review in acquittal appeals without rigid tests; High Court properly reviewed evidence of PW1, PW2, PW3, PW9-13 showing criminal force used against public servants discharging duties.

holdings.text: ss. 186 and 353, Indian Penal Code relate to two distinct offences with distinct ingredients; s.353 requires assault or criminal force while s.186 involves voluntary obstruction.

anchor.surface_text: but it cannot be ignored that ss. 186 and 353, Indian Penal Code relate to two distinct offences and while the offence under the latter section is a cognizable offence, the one under the former section is not so. The ingredients of the two offences are also distinct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual comparison of sections: s.186 in Ch.X (contempts of public authority), s.353 in Ch.XVI (offences to human body); different cognizability and essential elements.

holdings.text: s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but which is not within the ambit of that section.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-established that s. 195 of the Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same set of facts but which is not within the ambit of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed precedents like Satis Chandra, Basir-ul-Huq, Hori Ram; distinct offences can be prosecuted separately even on overlapping facts if not covered by s.195.

holdings.text: The conviction under s.353 IPC is not illegal due to contravention of s.195 CrPC; no camouflage or evasion as offences are genuinely distinct.

anchor.surface_text: we are of the opinion that S. 195, Criminal Procedure Code does not bar the trial of the appellants for the distinct offence under s. 353 of the Indian Penal Code, though it is practically based on the same facts as for the prosecution under s. 186... But we are satisfied that there is no substance in this argument and there is no camouflage or evasion in the present case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.353 requires criminal force (absent in s.186); prosecution not barred nor evasive; distinguished from cases of misdescription or wrong labelling.

precedents.cited_proposition: appellate court has full power to review the evidence upon which the order of acquittal is founded; principles in Sheo Swarup's case guide approach; no curtailment of power by phrases like substantial and compelling reasons; must express reasons why acquittal not justified

precedents.case_name: M. G. Agarwal v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: power conferred by cl. (a) of s. 423 CrPC on appeal against acquittal is as wide as cl. (b) against conviction; test of substantial and compelling reasons not rigid formula; no need to characterise findings as perverse

precedents.cited_proposition: where maker of single statement guilty of two distinct offences, one under s. 211 IPC against public justice requiring sanction, other under s. 499 defamation not requiring sanction, can take cognizance of latter without sanction as offences fundamentally distinct

precedents.cited_proposition: if allegations in false report disclose two distinct offences, one against public servant and other against private individual, s. 195 CrPC does not debar prosecution for the offence against private individual
